json\\objects\\ttp.title: TTP
json\\objects\\ttp.description: TTP describes an action taken by the insider or colluding outsider(s) during the course of the incident, categorized into a tactic, technique, and procedure (TTP). An incident may have multiple TTPs. A TTP must be connected to an incident.

id.description: A unique string that begins with "ttp--" and is appended with a UUIDv4

date.description: The date and time the action happened. If the action occurred over a range of time, use the start time of the action.

sequence_num.description: The sequence number of this action in the overall timeline of actions. It is helpful if the sequence of events is known, but the dates are unknown.

observed.description: Whether the action was observed by the victim organization or investigative team at the time it happened.

number_of_times.description: The number of times this particular action took place (e.g., subject issued "5" fraudulent checks over the course of three weeks)

ttp_vocab.description: A reference to the TTP framework being used by this TTP. Common options are IIDES, ATT&CK, CAPEC, etc.

tactic.description: The high-level category or goal of the action

technique.description: The general action taken. If technique exists, `tactic` should as well.

location.description: Whether the action was taken on site or remotely

hours.description: Whether the action was taken during work hours

device.description: The device where this action either took place or a device that was affected by the action. A device where the action could be detected.

channel.description: Methods used to transmit information outside or into the victim organization

description.description: Description of the action or procedure

oneOf.title: Access
oneOf.description: Insider uses an organizational account or access path to take an action related to the incident

oneOf.title: Recruitment
oneOf.description: Insider recruits or is recruited by others

oneOf.title: Financial Transaction
oneOf.description: Insider or colluding outsider makes a financial transaction related to the incident

oneOf.title: Malware
oneOf.description: Malicious software is used

oneOf.title: Malicous Action
oneOf.description: An intentionally malicious action not included in the other tactics

oneOf.title: Concealment
oneOf.description: Insider or colluding outsider takes an action that conceals or attempts to conceal their activity

oneOf.title: Data Exfiltration
oneOf.description: Data (or copies of data) is removed from the organization without permission or explicitly against permission to use in an unauthorized way

oneOf.title: Data Impact
oneOf.description: Harmful action involving the organization's data which compromises the organization in some way

oneOf.title: Safety Impact
oneOf.description: Harmful action involving the organization's personnel that compromises the safety of one or more individuals in the organization

oneOf.title: Own account
oneOf.description: Insider uses their granted access in order to commit their attack

oneOf.title: Privileged Access Abuse
oneOf.description: Insider uses their granted privileged access in order to commit their attack

oneOf.title: Shared Account
oneOf.description: Insider accesses an account they share with other employees

oneOf.title: Dormant or Expired Account
oneOf.description: Insider uses a company account that was either dormant or expired

oneOf.title: Unattended Workstation (Unsecured)
oneOf.description: Insider uses a workstation that was unassigned to an employee or uses a colleague's workstation when the colleague is not at their desk

oneOf.title: Own Account After Termination/Resignation
oneOf.description: Insider gains access to their company account after their termination date

oneOf.title: Compromised Account
oneOf.description: Insider uses the compromised account of another employee (e.g., the insider copied another employee's account and password prior to being terminated)

oneOf.title: Unauthorized Access Path
oneOf.description: Insider accesses systems using a previously unknown access path that they created (e.g., the insider used a backdoor account in order to gain access to the organization's systems)

oneOf.title: Authorized Third-Party Account
oneOf.description: Insider uses a third party account such as a vendor's account

oneOf.title: Coworker's Account
oneOf.description: Insider uses a coworker's account

oneOf.title: Customer's Account
oneOf.description: Insider uses a customer's account

oneOf.title: Database Administrator Account
oneOf.description: Insider uses a database administrator's account

oneOf.title: Supervisor's Account
oneOf.description: Insider uses their supervisor's account

oneOf.title: System Administrator Account
oneOf.description: Insider uses a system administrator's account

oneOf.title: Outsider Recruits Insider
oneOf.description: An outside entity that is not a competing organization encourages the insider to become an insider (e.g., the insider is contacted by known hacking specialist who asks the insider to divulge company secrets to the hacker)

oneOf.title: Insider Recruited Outside Aid
oneOf.description: The insider recruites people outside of the organization to further their scheme (e.g., the insider recruits their unemployed friend into the scheme)

oneOf.title: Insider Recruited Coworker(s)
oneOf.description: Insider recruits fellow employees to further their scheme

oneOf.title: Insider Recruited by Coworker(s)
oneOf.description: Insider is recruited by fellow employees to further their scheme

oneOf.title: Sells Information
oneOf.description: Insider or accomplice sells, or attempts to sell, organizational information, data, or property (e.g., the insider tried to sell company secrets on an online auction site)

oneOf.title: Payoffs From Insider
oneOf.description: Insider promises or gives other individuals or entities some amount of monetary compensation for aiding their scheme (e.g., the insider promises to give a fellow employee $1,000 if they steal confidential information)

oneOf.title: Payoffs to Insider
oneOf.description: Insider benefits financially or is promised compensation from an outside entity (e.g., a competing organization promises the insider $500 for every line of code stolen)

oneOf.title: Received/Transferred Fraudulent Funds
oneOf.description: Insider or accomplice receives or transfers funds that were fraudulently obtained (e.g., the insider took out cashier's checks on behalf of customers and used them for personal gain)

oneOf.title: Fraudulent Purchases
oneOf.description: Insider or accomplice uses fraudulently obtained funds to make purchases (e.g., the insider used general ledger funds from their organization to purchase cashier's checks in the amount of $10,000)

oneOf.title: Filed Fraudulent Tax Return
oneOf.description: Insider or accomplice files a fraudulent tax return. Often, this is using the identity of another person (e.g., the insider submitted multiple purported U.S. individual tax returns in the name of multiple people).

oneOf.title: Insider Created/Used Fraudulent Asset
oneOf.description: Insider creates an asset to use for future monetary gain (e.g., the insider defrauded the organization by providing false documentation claiming they wanted $250,000 to expand their business)

oneOf.title: Backdoor
oneOf.description: A malicious program that allows an attacker to perform actions on a remote system, such as transferring files, acquiring passwords, or executing arbitrary commands

oneOf.title: Bootkit
oneOf.description: A malicious program which targets the Master Boot Record of the target computer

oneOf.title: Keylogger
oneOf.description: The insider used either a hardware or software keylogger as part of their scheme

oneOf.title: Exploit Kit
oneOf.description: A software toolkit to target common vulnerabilities

oneOf.title: Ransomware
oneOf.description: A type of malware that encrypts files on a victim's system, demanding payment of ransom in return for the access codes required to unlock files

oneOf.title: Remote Access Trojan
oneOf.description: A remote access trojan program (or RAT) is a trojan horse capable of controlling a machine through commands issued by a remote attacker

oneOf.title: Resource Exploitation Software
oneOf.description: A type of malware that steals a system's resources (e.g., CPU cycles) such as a malicious bitcoin miner

oneOf.title: Rogue Security Software
oneOf.description: A fake security product that demands money to clean phony infections

oneOf.title: Rootkit
oneOf.description: A type of malware that hides its files or processes from normal methods of monitoring in order to conceal its presence and activities

oneOf.title: Screen Capture Software
oneOf.description: A type of malware used to capture images or video from the target systems screen, used for exfiltration and command and control

oneOf.title: Spyware
oneOf.description: Software that gathers information on a user's system without their knowledge and sends it to another party. Spyware is generally used to track activities for the purpose of delivering advertising.

oneOf.title: Logic Bomb
oneOf.description: A piece of code intentionally inserted into a software system that will set off a malicious function when specified conditions are met (e.g., a programmer may hide a piece of code that starts deleting files should they ever be terminated from the company)

oneOf.title: Wiper
oneOf.description: A piece of malware whose primary aim is to delete files or entire disks on a machine

oneOf.title: Bypassed Physical Security of Organizational Facilities
oneOf.description: Gains unauthorized physical access to organizational facilities (e.g., the insider gained access to the company building late on a Sunday night)

oneOf.title: Exploited Known Security Vulnerabilities
oneOf.description: Uses a security vulnerability known to the organization to further their scheme (e.g., the organization knew the insider didn't have a firewall on their computer but did nothing about it, and the insider was able to use this security vulnerability to compromise the system)

oneOf.title: Social Engineering of Employees
oneOf.description: Uses a social engineering technique as part of the attack (e.g., the insider sent a phishing e-mail to co-workers)

oneOf.title: Used/Executed Unauthorized Software
oneOf.description: Uses or executes any sort of unauthorized software on an organizational system (e.g., the insider used a credit card skimmer in order to obtain customer PII). This grouping includes installing or running unauthorized software.

oneOf.title: Falsified Information
oneOf.description: Insider or accomplice manipulates information or identity falsely to aid in their attack (e.g., the insider falsely signed a claim stating that they returned all organizational property upon resignation)

oneOf.title: Omitted Information
oneOf.description: Insider or accomplice manipulates information or identity through omission to aid in their attack (e.g., the insider omits previous work for a competitor during a background check)

oneOf.title: Modified/Deleted Logs/Activity
oneOf.description: Insider or accomplice deletes or modifies log files or other information that would connect them to the incident (e.g., the insider tried to conceal their communications with their accomplice by deleting files from their personal email account)

oneOf.title: Physically Destroyed/Hid Evidence
oneOf.description: Insider or accomplice physically destroys or hides evidence that would connect them to the incident (e.g., the insider shredded papers containing employee PII that they had printed out to commit credit card fraud)

oneOf.title: Fled or Attempted to Flee
oneOf.description: Insider or accomplice flees or attempts to flee their home state in order to avoid detection of their scheme (e.g., the insider fled the country)

oneOf.title: Created/Used an Alias
oneOf.description: Insider or accomplice uses the identity of another person (e.g., the insider went under the alias "John Doe" when conducting business in their startup to cover their tracks)

oneOf.title: Framed another Individual
oneOf.description: Insider or accomplice takes steps to plant evidence or otherwise falsely prove that someone else committed the insider's actions

oneOf.title: False Statements/Denied Involvement
oneOf.description: Insider or accomplice makes any sort of statement that is false or denys their involvement in the incident (e.g., the insider lied to their supervisor, saying that they had not taken confidential information from them when they actually did)

oneOf.title: Concealment of Current Illicit Activity - Other Technical
oneOf.description: Any other technical method used by the insider or accomplice in an attempt to hide malicious activities

oneOf.title: Concealment of Current Illicit Activity - Other Non-Technical
oneOf.description: Any other non-technical method used by the insider or accomplice in an attempt to hide malicious activities

oneOf.title: Paper
oneOf.description: Data exfiltration through printed or hand-written materials (e.g., the insider takes screenshots of important data, prints the screenshots, and walks out of work with them)

oneOf.title: Removable Media
oneOf.description: Data exfiltration through digital equipment or media (e.g., the insider had trade secrets owned by the victim organization on a flash drive and sent the flash drive to the competitor to be copied)

oneOf.title: Email
oneOf.description: Data exfiltration through electronic mail (e.g., the insider e-mailed confidential information to competitor)

oneOf.title: Cloud Storage
oneOf.description: Data exfiltration to external cloud storage (e.g., the insider downloaded company PII and uploaded it to their personal Box account)

oneOf.title: Web-Based
oneOf.description: Data exfiltration to any based with the World Wide Web (e.g., the insider posted the stolen employee PII to the Internet). The category includes data exfiltrated over various web protocols that are not covered more specifically by another grouping, such as exfiltration using the File Transfer Protocol (FTP) or exfiltration over a Virtual Private Network (VPN).

oneOf.title: Verbal
oneOf.description: Data exfiltration by stating it verbally to someone else

oneOf.title: Mobile Device
oneOf.description: Data exfiltration via mobile device

oneOf.title: Laptop
oneOf.description: Data exfiltration by taking it out of the organization on a laptop

oneOf.title: Other Technical/Digital
oneOf.description: Data exfiltration using other technical or digital means not listed in this vocabulary

oneOf.title: Other Non-Technical
oneOf.description: Data exfiltration using other non-technical means not listed in this vocabulary

oneOf.title: Physical Attack to Organizational Equipment
oneOf.description: Insider or accomplice physically harms any of the organization's physical equipment (e.g., the insider pours glue into USB ports in all desktops)

oneOf.title: Modified Critical Data
oneOf.description: Insider or accomplice modifies data that is critical to the victim organization (e.g., the insider was able to remotely access the victim organization's systems to modify employee information and change passwords)

oneOf.title: Deleted Critical Data
oneOf.description: Insider or accomplice deletes data that is critical to the victim organization (e.g., the insider was able to remotely access the victim organization's systems to delete files)

oneOf.title: Used Data in Identity Theft
oneOf.description: Insider or accomplice uses data to pretend to be someone else (e.g., to submit false tax returns, open bank accounts, etc.)

oneOf.title: Posted Data Publicly
oneOf.description: Posted internal, sensitive, or confidential data in a public forum

oneOf.title: Sold or Gave Away Critical Data
oneOf.description: Sold or gave away internal data to an external individual or company

oneOf.title: Doxxed Individuals
oneOf.description: Publicly posted information about individuals (customers or employees) online for purpose of instigating outside harassment

oneOf.title: Threatened Violence
oneOf.description: Threatened violence or physical harm against other individuals in the organization

oneOf.title: Threatened Suicide
oneOf.description: Threated physical harm to theirself

oneOf.title: Attempted Violence
oneOf.description: Attempted violence or physical harm against other individuals in the organization (successful or unsuccesful)

oneOf.title: Attempted Suicide
oneOf.description: Attempted physical harm to theirself (successful or unsuccessful)

oneOf.title: On-site
oneOf.description: Action taken while on site at an organizational facility

oneOf.title: Remotely
oneOf.description: Action taken while remote (i.e., not at an organizational facility)

oneOf.title: Remotely from home
oneOf.description: Action taken remotely while at the insider's or accomplice's home

oneOf.title: Remotely while traveling
oneOf.description: Action remotely while traveling

oneOf.title: During Work Hours
oneOf.description: Insider took the action during their normal working hours

oneOf.title: Outside of Work Hours
oneOf.description: Insider took the action outside of their normal working hours

oneOf.title: Company Desktop
oneOf.description: Organization owned desktop workstation

oneOf.title: Company Laptop
oneOf.description: Organization owned laptop workstation

oneOf.title: Company Mobile Device
oneOf.description: Organization owned mobile device

oneOf.title: Database Server
oneOf.description: Database server

oneOf.title: Email Server
oneOf.description: Email server

oneOf.title: File Server
oneOf.description: File server

oneOf.title: Personal Computer
oneOf.description: Personally owned computer

oneOf.title: Personal Mobile Device
oneOf.description: Personally owned mobile device

oneOf.title: Printer/Copier/Fax
oneOf.description: Printer, copier, or fax machine

oneOf.title: Web Server
oneOf.description: Web server

oneOf.title: Other
oneOf.description: Other device not in this vocabulary

oneOf.title: Company Email
oneOf.description: An email account the company controls

oneOf.title: Company Phone
oneOf.description: A phone the company controls

oneOf.title: Instant Messaging
oneOf.description: Direct, synchronous or asynchronous communication via app, software, or web

oneOf.title: Online Forum
oneOf.description: Private or public forum accessed via the Internet

oneOf.title: Personal Email
oneOf.description: An email account the organization does not control or monitor

oneOf.title: Personal Phone
oneOf.description: A phone the organization does not control or monitor

oneOf.title: Other
oneOf.description: Other type of channel not listed in this vocabulary

json\\structs\\collusion.title: Collusion
json\\structs\\collusion.description: Collusion represents the relationship between insiders. For the purposes of the `recruitment` property, insider1 recruited insider2.

id.description: A unique string that begins with "collusion--" and is appended with a UUIDv4

relationship.description: The type of relationship between insider1 and insider2

oneOf.title: Avoid Detection
oneOf.description: Insider1 needed insider2's access or authorization to avoid detection

oneOf.title: Greater Payoff
oneOf.description: Insider1 received a greater payoff by recruiting insider2

oneOf.title: Insider Resigned
oneOf.description: Insider1 no longer worked at the victim organization and needed insider2 to finish the incident

oneOf.title: Separation of Duties
oneOf.description: Insider1 could not conduct acheive their goals without insider2 due to a separation of duties which limited their access of authorization

oneOf.title: Share the Wealth
oneOf.description: Insider1 recruited insider2 due to a desire to share the wealth

oneOf.title: Other
oneOf.description: Insider1 recruited insider2 for unknown reasons

json\\structs\\org-owner.title: Org Owner
json\\structs\\org-owner.description: Org Owner describes the relationship for a person owning an organization. The person can be either an accomplice or an insider to the incident.

id.description: A unique string that begins with "org-owner--" and is appended with a UUIDv4

person.description: The `id` of the insider or accomplice who owns the organization

org.description: The `id` of the organization object that is owned by the insider or accomplice

json\\structs\\org-relationship.title: Org Relationship
json\\structs\\org-relationship.description: Org Relationship describes the relationship between two organizations involved in an incident.

id.description: A unique string that begins with "org-relationship--" and is appended with a UUIDv4

org1.description: The `id` of the first organization object

org2.description: The `id` of the second organization object

relationship.description: Defines the relationship between the two organizations. Reads as "Org1 is [relationship] to Org2" (e.g., "Org1 is vendor to Org2").

anyOf.title: Competitor
anyOf.description: Org1 and Org2 compete with each for the same customers

anyOf.title: Parent
anyOf.description: Org1 is a parent company to Org2

anyOf.title: Subsidiary
anyOf.description: Org1 is a subsidiary (child company) to Org2

anyOf.title: Vendor
anyOf.description: Org1 provides goods, materials, or services to Org2 on a contractual basis

anyOf.title: Trusted Business Partner
anyOf.description: A trusted business partner is an organization or individual that has an alliance (contractually, bonded, etc.) with the victim organization

anyOf.title: Other
anyOf.description: Other type of relationship not described by this vocabulary
